history.content: Ask yourself why you're failing the interviews you're getting. Try to work harder on your weaknesses and instead of blindly doing Leetcode questions (the number doesn't matter), focus specifically on concepts/topics that are challenging for you. If you think your English accent or communication is problem, work on that, have mock interviews with your friends, etc. Get your resume reviewed by someone experienced or an adviser. Also 89 is a relatively small number, I did not keep an exact count but I had to apply to over 200 companies before I got an offer (when I didn't have any experience).

children.subject: Also, personal tip, but try to block out what everyone else is up to and how they're doing on the internship hunt and focus solely on applying, improving your own resume, and grinding LC. It can get pretty depressing to hear about otherwise average students landing FAANG, Big N and unicorn offers when you don't have anything to show for your own self despite putting in at least as much if not more work than them. Good luck.

Thank you for your detailed response. I actually had my resume reviewed by the ESS but I guess is just my lack of experience what is preventing me of getting more callbacks. Wow my callback rate is just pathetic. Given the time I have from here to the last-minute hires happening in April next year, I think there is not much thing I can do to significantly improve my chances of getting something other than practicing and applying. I wish I think being a transfer plays a role when looking for jobs since it has happened to me that some recruiters at careers fairs say, "so you are a transfer, huh?" as if I were not worthy for an interview op. Also, since I am almost a decade older than the average senior student (not everyone can go straight to University after high school for financial issues, you know) so I have a feeling they have a bias for younger minds. Again, thank you for your observations and best wishes to your future academic/career goals.

I would definitely try working on a personal project over the winter break, something that you can talk about and involves technologies across the stack. Doing so, and putting it and the technologies you used to create it on your resume will definitely help your resume between now and April, besides giving you something to talk about in interviews. Besides that, look into rewriting certain parts of your resume in a more technical fashion if possible, and make sure to convey the technologies/languages/frameworks you used for whatever projects/experience you already have on there. If possible and applicable, also mention numbers and statistics (such as X no. of downloads for an app in the first month, no. of users per month etc.). Other than that, as you already realized, keep practicing and applying. 

I'm not sure how transfers are viewed in the eyes of recruiters, but know that you're not alone and regular students like myself with regular academic paths have struggled as much with the recruiting process as you have, and that while it isn't easy to get that first bit of actual industry experience, it only gets easier once you do.

Actually, this is my plan and I have already have something started. I want to apply some cool stuff I learned this semester. Something that I might explore is mobile app development since having worked on an app seems to be a good conversation starter. Thank you once again for you time!

Sidenote, but 89 is a pretty small number. For reference, I applied to 220+ different companies this year as a junior before I got an offer, and this was after internship experience at a smaller company in the Bay last summer. The year before, I lost track but the number might have easily been twice that. 

Also, you need to evaluate which step of the process you're failing more often than you should be. Is your callback rate after applying really low (say <10%)? If so, then your resume might be a problem, and you'll need to work on improving it. Or are you getting enough callbacks, but are unable to pass  interviews? If so, then you're going to have to do an autopsy of what went wrong in the interview, if anything, and other potential red flags that you think were raised that caused the interviewer to reject you. You mention that you have only got 3 callbacks from 89 applications this year, and 5 from 150 last year. This is good for a ~3.33% callback rate, and that is a number that you can definitely bring up by working on your resume, via personal projects and/or research experience if you have the GPA to obtain it. As a sophomore I only really had some research experience via URAP and my personal projects were literally just lower div projects and it took me, like I said, probably 400+ applications to land an offer. My callback rate back then was about 5%, and with the added experience, my callback rate was bumped up to 11-12% this year. 

Finally, keep grinding LC even if you're unable to get many interviews as you work on your resume, as it can really help you stay sharp for any interviews that may appear out of nowhere. I regret not having done any LC over the summer after I landed my sophomore internship, and that definitely cost me in some interviews for next year's internships as I was rusty. It's all a numbers game.

I have applied, and got rejected :(. TA applications felt somewhat similar to some industry interviews. They asked me where I have interned before, what teaching experience I have, and if I have done research. I know TAs are also hot positions here and I know there are a lot of bright minds who easily shade us all regular beings. In any case, thank you for your kind suggestion.

No problem. Unsure if this is your goal, but I see in another post you are a bit older than average seniors. Perhaps pursuing a Master's degree after graduating might help you if you are not satisfied with your resume by the time you graduate or the offer you get. But if that's not something you want to do I completely understand. Good luck though!
that's something very plausible. I am thinking in both regular masters and the 5th year master as well. Not sure if I need research experience for the latter, though. I need read more about it.

It may be a bit late for the OP to become a TA, but for anyone else reading this, generally the best path to become a TA is through CSM/tutoring. It's really hard to get hired as a TA without either of those. Just for 61a summer applications last summer, I think the number was about 200 applications for only 5 or 6 open spots.
Have you looked into become a TA for a class? That can probably help with the experience aspect you say you are lacking.

At this point, I thing I would pay for one like Berkeley's Global internship where you literally pay for everything to relocate in to work unpaid. Although I would preferably work anywhere nationwide. I will be my winter break goal to apply for 50 more companies, trying to complete yet another side project, and re-re-refine my resume. I might be unwanted but I'll do my best to get something hopefully not too bad.

Hi Bro, 

            I don't have any internship so far and I am also looking , there is a website called internships.com where u might find unpaid internships which I think are easier to get (if you can afford to do those) , just an advice.

Hey OP! I am a graduating transfer senior also, not quite a decade older than traditional students, but just about ;)  
All it takes is one! I applied over 200 interships/full time roles too! Try career Fair, messaging/connecting on LinkedIn directly, referrals also, if you haven't already. Also, after I failed 1 or 2 interviews, I read a lot about interviews from the hiring-side perspective, talked to people I knew who had graduated and started being interviewers, and that helped me calibrate my "performance" during interview. 

It's tough as a transfer student (can be tough for everyone, as poster above pointed out), it's a tight timeline. It's clear your determined to get this, you've worked hard, your smart-- a numbers game this is, nothing personal about it. It's coming! :)

history.content: I am a senior transfer student and I am getting very frustrated for not getting any internship offer so far in my entire Cal journey. It is particularly interesting that some of my friends who tend to have a challenging time learning coding skills and keep seeking my help  have already got internships. I've applied to over 89 companies this fall and I have gotten 3 interviews already but I never get pass the 2nd or final rounds. I have applied to wide range of companies from baby startups to the big 5 companies and nothing. Last academic year I sent about 150 applications and got 5 interviews (1 of them with the top 5) and I failed all of them. People always tell me to keep applying (which I do almost on weekly basis) but that argument would be completely valid if I were applying to less than 50 companies. I am not sure if is just bias for the way I look, my English accent, etc. I usually do well to very well in most my classes. I have done lots and lost of Leetcode and Hackerrank problems too. The only thing I don't have is prior experience so I have nothing to show other than academic and interesting personal projects. I think I am in the borderline of getting depressed :( since I know without internship will be trice as hard to get a full time offer.
history.subject: No internships = no future?
